channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: MPs say yes to three-person babies
item.description: In an historic move, MPs have voted overwhelmingly in favour of the creation of babies with DNA from two women and one man.

item.title: Lee to publish Mockingbird 'sequel'
item.description: An unpublished novel by Harper Lee is to finally see the light of day, 60 years after the US author put it aside to write To Kill a Mockingbird.

item.title: Redknapp resigns as QPR manager
item.description: Harry Redknapp resigns as manager of Premier League strugglers QPR because of an upcoming knee operation.

item.title: French soldiers hurt in knife attack
item.description: Three soldiers on an anti-terror patrol in Nice, southern France, are lightly wounded in knife attack, French police say.

item.title: TV star's trial halted by fall
item.description: The trial of former TV weather presenter Fred Talbot is halted after he was injured when he tripped leaving the witness box.

item.title: England will control own tax - Hague
item.description: Scottish MPs would lose the right to impose income tax, schools and health changes on England under proposals outlined by Commons Leader William Hague.

item.title: Litvinenko 'did not poison himself'
item.description: Former Russian spy Alexander Litvinenko did not accidentally kill himself after handling nuclear material, his widow tells the inquiry into his death.

item.title: Courts can impose whole-life terms
item.description: British courts do have the right to impose whole-life tariffs on prisoners who are jailed for life, the European Court of Human Rights rules.

item.title: Salvadorean priest 'a martyr' - Pope
item.description: Pope Francis approves martyrdom status for murdered Salvadorean Archbishop Oscar Romero, paving the way for beatification.

item.title: Energy price sites earn £30 a switch
item.description: The big five energy comparison sites have admitted they earn up to £30 in commission every time a customer switches provider

item.title: Williams family fights over estate
item.description: Robin Williams' widow and children go to court in a dispute over the late comedian's estate.

item.title: Sky claims Open golf live TV rights
item.description: Sky will broadcast the Open Championship from 2017 after buying exclusive rights, while the BBC will show daily highlights.

item.title: Reinvigorated Obama snaps into action
item.description: President Obama has confounded predictions that the rest of his term would amount to two years of drift, says Jamie Coomarasamy.

item.title: Are we missing the real student loan story?
item.description: The debate over tuition fees has drowned out problems with student maintenance loans, says Sean Coughlan.

item.title: Why Syriza wants a five-month cool-off
item.description: The Greek finance minister told me how he with his "left-wing heart" is making common cause with hedge fund managers and bankers

item.title: Babies created from three people
item.description: The UK is set to become the first place in the world to approve the creation of babies from the DNA of three people. BBC News explores the technology.

item.title: Why engineering should be a woman's game
item.description: More girls should be encouraged to study engineering, says Dame Ann Dowling - we need them.

item.title: VIDEO: Ebola crisis: is the outbreak over?
item.description: Cases of Ebola in West Africa have reached their lowest level in months; is the worst of the outbreak now over?

item.title: Lost chunk of historic computer found
item.description: Efforts to recreate one of the earliest computers are aided by the recovery of a part of the original machine, which had been bought to create bookshelves.

item.title: 'Satanic capital' claims dismissed
item.description: Satanists dismiss claims that a Derbyshire district is a "hotbed of Satanism" or the "Satanic capital of Britain".

item.title: VIDEO: Close-up: Meet football's £1bn agent
item.description: In an interview with the BBC's sports editor Dan Roan, Portuguese football agent Jorge Mendes defends the amount of money in the game.

item.title: Froch vacates IBF belt & plots return
item.description: Carl Froch vacates his IBF super-middleweight title, leaving mandatory challenger James DeGale to fight for the belt.

item.title: McLaren make testing breakthrough
item.description: McLaren finally make a breakthrough on the third day of testing and manage to put mileage on their new car and Honda engine.

item.title: January signings: 10 unusual facts
item.description: Ultimate frisbee, debut-delaying socks, and ocean-inspired names - read our alternative facts on the transfer window signings.

item.title: Ronaldo worth at least £300m - agent
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo would sell for at least £300m if Real Madrid decided to let him go, according to the player's agent.

item.title: Lower oil price hits BP profits
item.description: BP reports a fall in underlying profits and says it will reduce spending on exploration because of lower oil prices.

item.title: Ocado reports first annual profit
item.description: Online grocer Ocado reports a full-year pre-tax profit for the first time since launching in 2000 as sales jump to almost £1bn.

item.title: Boris Johnson enters Boots tax row
item.description: Boris Johnson says it is "disappointing" retailer Boots does not pay more tax in the UK - amid a row between the stores chain and Labour.

item.title: Darling: I'd share Salmond platform
item.description: Alistair Darling tells the BBC that he would be willing to share a platform with Alex Salmond during any EU referendum campaign.

item.title: Too much jogging is 'unhealthy'
item.description: Too much jogging may be as bad for you as not putting on your running shoes at all, a report in the journal of the American College of Cardiology says.

item.title: More Scots waiting longer in A&E
item.description: New figures suggest Scotland's accident and emergency departments treated 91% of patients within four hours between October and December.

item.title: Autism provision appeals on the rise
item.description: More families of children with autism in England are taking legal action against their local authority over special needs provision.

item.title: Cameron challenged on pupil funding
item.description: David Cameron promises not to cut school budgets for a rising number of pupils in a future Conservative government, but funding will not be protected against inflation.

item.title: Google and Uber may become rivals
item.description: Uber announces plans to research driverless cars while a report claims Google is considering launching a lift-hailing service

item.title: 'Revenge porn' site owner convicted
item.description: A man who ran a "revenge porn" site faces up to 20 years in prison after being convicted of identity theft and extortion.

item.title: Drug-delivery engineer wins £1m prize
item.description: A pioneer of medical technologies that have benefited millions of people is the latest winner of the Queen Elizabeth Prize for Engineering.

item.title: Ex-science chief: GM tech 'is safe'
item.description: The technology behind GM crops is safe, according to scientific consensus, says the outgoing science adviser to the European Commission.

item.title: 'No diversity quota' for EastEnders
item.description: EastEnders boss Dominic Treadwell-Collins says he will not bring minority characters into the BBC soap just to fulfil diversity quotas.

item.title: UK film production 'surged' in 2014
item.description: More money was spent making films in the UK last year than in any other year since measurements began, figures from the British Film Institute reveal.

item.title: A slight hijacking of a logo
item.description: Andy Murray's fiancee Kim Sears wore a Parental Advisory sweatshirt during the Australian Open final.

item.title: The great Kuwaiti cat-meat scandal
item.description: In 1930s Kuwait, an accusation that a restaurant owner was serving cat meat caused uproar - but British diplomats rode to the rescue of the unlucky man, writes Matthew Teller.

item.title: Slaughterhouse animal 'abuse' probed
item.description: Four men at a North Yorkshire slaughterhouse have their operating licences suspended after hidden cameras film alleged mistreatment of animals.

item.title: Man jailed for potato masher attack
item.description: A man who attacked a 75-year-old man with a potato masher and poker, leaving him for dead, is jailed for life.

item.title: Bottle smashed young boy's teeth out
item.description: A young Rangers fan has been speaking about getting hit in the face by a bottle on the way to the Old Firm game.

item.title: Delay for Kelpies visitor centre
item.description: Plans for a new £1.8m visitor centre at the Kelpies attraction in Falkirk are expanded, delaying its opening by several months.

item.title: Huge increase in drug finds in jail
item.description: There has been a huge increase in the number of drugs finds in Northern Ireland's only high-security jail over the past two years, the BBC has learned.

item.title: Golfer's court case delayed further
item.description: Rory McIlroy's court case against his former management agent is adjourned until Wednesday in the Irish High Court.

item.title: Golfer accused of £26k benefit fraud
item.description: A man who claimed he could not walk far and received £26,000 in disability benefits was a champion golfer, a court hears.

item.title: 'Reckless' driver in train near-miss
item.description: A motorist is fined after he drives his car across a railway track in front of an oncoming train.

item.title: Chad troops join Nigeria battle
item.description: Chadian troops backed by air strikes enter north-eastern Nigeria to join the battle against Islamist militant group Boko Haram.

item.title: Journalist gives up Egypt passport
item.description: Al-Jazeera journalist Mohamed Fahmy renounces his Egyptian citizenship to secure his release from jail after the deportation of Peter Greste.

item.title: Most China cities fail air test
item.description: The Chinese government says only eight of the country's 74 biggest cities met its own basic air quality standards in 2014.

item.title: Death penalty for S Korea soldier
item.description: A South Korean soldier who shot dead five of his colleagues and injured seven others is sentenced to death by a military court.

item.title: New Ukraine clashes 'catastrophic'
item.description: Up to 16 civilians are killed in the space of 24 hours in eastern Ukraine, as the UN warns that the renewed fighting is "catastrophic" for civilians.

item.title: Court rejects Balkan genocide claims
item.description: The top UN court rejects claims by Serbia and Croatia of genocide against each other during the war which saw the break-up of Yugoslavia.

item.title: New Fidel Castro pictures released
item.description: A series of photographs showing Cuban ex-President Fidel Castro are published in Cuban state media following speculation about his health.

item.title: US expands Venezuela visa bans
item.description: The United States imposes visa restrictions on unnamed Venezuelan officials over alleged human rights violations and corruption.

item.title: UN Gaza probe head quits over 'bias'
item.description: The head of a UN inquiry into last year's conflict in Gaza resigns amid Israeli allegations of bias over his former work with the PLO.

item.title: UN alarm over 'IS logo' on food aid
item.description: The UN says it is "extremely concerned" by pictures which appear to show the logo of the Islamic State militant group on its food aid to Syria.

item.title: S&P pays $1.4bn in sub-prime case
item.description: Credit rating agency Standard & Poor's (S&P) agrees to pay $1.38bn settlement to US regulators over allegations it knowingly inflated its ratings of risky mortgage investments.

item.title: Web rallies around walking commuter
item.description: Donations flood in for a Detroit, Michigan, man who walks 21 miles as part of his daily commute after a newspaper tells his story.

item.title: Day in pictures: 3 February 2015
item.description: Images from around the world: 3 February

item.title: In pictures: Living beside the tracks
item.description: Families living right beside a railway

item.title: Rediscovered pictures from Spanish Civil War
item.description: New trove of pictures from Spanish Civil War

item.title: In pictures: Churchill celebrated
item.description: Anniversary of Sir Winston Churchill's state funeral

item.title: Day in pictures: 2 February 2015
item.description: Images from around the world: 2 February

item.title: Week in pictures: 24-30 January 2015
item.description: News photos from around the world

item.title: In pictures: Destruction in Kobane
item.description: Devastation caused by fighting in Syrian town

item.title: Day in pictures: 30 January 2015
item.description: Images from around the world: 30 January

item.title: VIDEO: Home Affairs Committee
item.description: MPs are taking evidence on counter-terrorism.

item.title: VIDEO: Time-lapse shows build up of US Snow
item.description: Time-lapse video shows the gradual build up of snow as residents in Poughkeepsie, New York are hit by a blizzard.

item.title: VIDEO: Footage exposes abattoir cruelty
item.description: One man has been sacked and three others have had their operating licences suspended after hidden cameras filmed alleged mistreatment of animals at a North Yorkshire slaughterhouse.

item.title: VIDEO: Plan to lift huge oil platform by boat
item.description: Shell is proposing a plan to lift the entire Brent Delta platform, one of the North Sea's original, onto ships for dismantling at a dry dock.

item.title: VIDEO: Revitalising areas with £1 homes
item.description: Rising property prices have made it increasingly difficult for people to get on the property ladder, but councils in Stoke and Liverpool have been tackling the issue with innovative schemes.

item.title: VIDEO: The Balkans genocide cases explained
item.description: Judges at the highest court of the United Nations are ruling on genocide cases between Croatia and Serbia.

item.title: VIDEO: Bus roof 'peels off' after hitting tree
item.description: The roof of a bus has been ripped off after it hit overhanging trees in central London.

item.title: VIDEO: Childhood abuse: Surviving the pain
item.description: Fergal Keane speaks to survivors of child abuse and hears their stories of survival.

item.title: VIDEO: Footage shows huge starling formation
item.description: A murmuration, or flock, of starlings flew spectacularly in the sky near Rahat in Israel.

item.title: Boko Haram attack: What happened in Baga?
item.description: What happened when Boko Haram attacked Baga?

item.title: In pictures: UK snow 3 February 2015
item.description: Parts of UK wake up to blanket of snow

item.title: The men of steel with a softer side
item.description: The family that gave most of its business to charities

item.title: The scale of abuse
item.description: How much child abuse takes place in the UK?

item.title: HS2 Bill tackles the nitty-gritty
item.description: Members of the public put their concerns over HS2 to MPs

item.title: How accurate are 'due dates'?
item.description: But what's the chance both babies will be born on the same day?

item.title: Minimising the hacker threat
item.description: If a cyber-attack is unpreventable, what can you do?

item.title: VIDEO: Vatican priests who are also recession astrophysicists
item.description: The Jesuit priests who are also astrophysicists
